entry.title: Combined summary - Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: Antoine Riard, Nicholas Gregory, and Ray Youssef are working on a peer-to-peer market system called CivKit. CivKit aims to enable censorship-resistant and permissionless global trading. The design of CivKit combines the Nostr architecture with Lightning onion routing infrastructure to ensure confidentiality for market participants. The market boards in CivKit are Nostr relays with a Lightning gateway and can be operated independently or as part of a federation.Trades in CivKit are escrowed using Bitcoin Script contracts and rely on moderations and know your peer oracles for adjudication. The process starts with Mary the Maker publishing a limit order to buy a derivative. Bob, the bulletin board operator, has the option to execute against Mary's order. If Bob doesn't want to execute, he relays the order to Terry the Taker (and other subscribers to Bob's market). Terry then has the option to execute a trade against Mary's limit order. If Terry decides not to execute, Mary's order sits on the bulletin board. This model resembles more of a brokerage rather than an exchange market structure.Front-running is a concern in CivKit, defined as entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security. However, the conversation suggests that front-running may not be a significant concern because if Bob can collect outsized profits as the bulletin board operator, Terry will eventually move to other markets.To mitigate front-running risks, different security paradigms are discussed in the conversation. One approach is to duplicate the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities and monitor latency anomalies. Another approach is to run the bulletin boards as a federation using Honey Badger BFT or similar techniques. These paradigms can adapt to different types of trades and market participants' tolerance.The conversation also emphasizes the importance of providing a good user experience and identifying the products people are interested in trading. It suggests that addressing these aspects will lead to other elements falling into place. The reputation of trades, counterparties, and service operators can be enabled through a Web-of-Stakes, where economic weight is assigned to each market entity based on the Bitcoin UTXO set. An incentive framework backed by privacy-preserving credentials and Bitcoin payments is proposed to incentivize efficiency among service operators.Overall, Antoine, Nicholas, and Ray are developing CivKit as a flexible framework for peer-to-peer marketplaces. They aim to create a censorship-resistant and permissionless trading environment while ensuring a good user experience. The system considers front-running resistance as a parameter that can be adjusted based on real-world deployments. The researchers plan to release code and modules gradually, collaborate with the community, and standardize libraries to ensure interoperability between clients.
